title: Has there ever been a fretless electric bass player that could come anywhere close to Jaco Pastorius's playing? - Quora

response.answer_text: If you were asking Jaco himself this question? He’d say “That’s easy man! Check out Alphonso! ..hell! He was in Weather Report before I was! Alphonso is the real deal!” Then Jaco would say- “There’s one other tough mother fucker on fretless besides Alphonso..that Ralphe Armstrong guy! He’s as tough as they come!” So first- Alphonso Weather Report (Live) - Cucumber Slumber  Alphonso Johnson is a superb fretless bassist..he started out playing upright and replaced Miroslav on bass in Weather Report..he did two albums before Jaco joined and played on most of “Black Market” as well..it seems that a lot of people don’t know that!  Jaco played on “Black Market” of course but not the entire album.(“Cannonball” & “Barbary Coast”)  ”Mysterious Traveller” is an extraordinary album by Weather Report and Alphonso absolutely destroys on it! After Jaco joined Zawinul and Shorter, Alphonso went with Billy Cobham and George Duke.   A young pre Miles Davis John Scofield was also in the band on a Humbucker equipped Les Paul Junior! Make no mistake- This band was insane. Bill Cobham / George Duke Band - Red Baron Alphonso also plays fretted bass with authority-and he is accomplished on Chapman Stick!  Next Ralphe Armstrong  Ralphe Armstrong has played fretless with everyone..but most known to me is the third version of Mahavishnu Orchestra with Narada Michael Walden on drums..  Ralphe also has played a lot with Jean Luc Ponty these days..as recently as last August as far as I know! He is a menace on electric fretless and like Alphonso, started out on double bass..  This video I’ve posted from YouTube is long..you don’t have to watch the whole thing if you don’t want to-but you should! LOL (Shout out to “Big I’ve” and “Detroit Bass Players” from “The BassMint” who put out innumerable bass videos on YouTube and recorded this video of Ralphe) BASSIST RALPHE ARMSTRONG INTERVIEW IN THE BASSMINT Here’s a current photo of Ralphe from a Warwick advertisement  Alphonso Johnson and Ralphe Armstrong are my answer to your question..I truly believe that Jaco would agree with me too. Best!

If you're asking if there's anyone who's played the bass as quickly, fluently and musically as Jaco, I would suggest, Michael Manring, Mark Egan (student of Jaco), and Steve Bailey to name a few.  With a little time you might even find a few unknown cats on You Tube.  However, this does no discredit to Jaco or his bass-playing legacy.  Jaco was and will always be a unique and monumental talent in the musical world due to his pioneering techniques, innovative creativity and monstrous playing of the bass guitar.  Jaco's playing made the bass guitar a lead instrument and opened the door for so many great talents who have continued to demonstrate the melodic value and versatility of this instrument.  His work on the fretless with the use of harmonics was (to my knowledge) unheard of before he came along (listen to Portrait of Tracy).  Pioneers pave a way for the next generations.  They take the biggest risks, the greatest falls, and sometimes never realize the significance of their work. Jaco taught us that anything is possible with this instrument.  Explore, ask questions, experiment and by all means, work your butt off to make it happen!  So, the fact that there are, in my opinion, a number of bassists who play as well as Jaco is a credit to Jaco and his legacy.  Although his bass-playing ability will be surpassed, Jaco's legacy is one that continues to grow with every innovative, hard working bassist throughout the world who has been inspired by this giant!

If you're looking for a unique voice, originality and innovation - the late great Mick Karn is the one to check out. He wasn't a virtuoso like Jaco, but his playing never ceases to inspire me. His approach to the bass was absolutely one of a kind. To really hear what I'm talking about, I recomment Japan's "Still Life in Mobile Homes" from the "Oil On Canvas" live album. Also Pino Palladino and John Giblin are truly worth listening to.

There’s loads of players today that can play / copy what he did. Just as there’s loads of guitarists who can play Hendrix’s lines as well as he did. There’s two points for me here 1 - Jaco, like Hendrix, was the First. The first to bring revolutionary techniques and musical approaches to the fore. He reset the game. 2 - Jaco was more than ‘just’ a bass player. He was primarily a fantastic musician - both as composer, and arranger. There’s a thousand bedroom YouTubers that can ape his level of technical proficiency, but none of them are even in the same musical universe as him.

I don't think so, and I think there are a couple of reasons.  First, he did not play an off the shelf bass--he created his own fretless bass by removing the frets from his Fender, and then coating the neck with marine epoxy.  Second, he came from a rhythm and blues background, and he brought this to the jazz world.

Jaco has been a pioneer in the field of the fretless. But judging the newcomers in the footsteps of Jaco doesn't really do justice to them. Though Jaco has influenced many bassists considerably, they have still developed their unique styles and tones. Many amazing bassists have already been mentioned in the other posts. I think Alain Caron also makes it to the list. We do see some Jaco in his playing.
Yes, Pino Palladino. Not the same, maybe not as "good" artistically, but excellent nonetheless.
What about Les Claypool?  Doesn't he have the technical proficiency at the fretless bass to be considered in this conversation ?
